trait.name: Devil's Sight
entries: Magical darkness doesn't impede the devil's darkvision.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The devil has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Hell Rider
entries: While mounted, the devil has advantage on melee attack rolls against unmounted creatures smaller than its mount.

trait.name: Scalding Strike
entries: When the devil deals fire damage to a creature, that creature can't use reactions until its next turn.

trait.name: Crucible of Courage
entries: An enemy that starts its turn within 30 feet of the devil that can see it must make a {@dc 12} Wisdom saving throw, provided that the devil isn't {@condition incapacitated}. On a failed save, the creature is {@condition frightened} for 1 minute. A {@condition frightened} target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. Once it succeeds on the saving throw, the creature is immune to the Crucible of Courage of all devils for 24 hours.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The devil makes two melee attacks. It can use Hurl Flame in place of any melee attack.

action.name: Lance
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 1d12 + 3}) piercing damage plus 10 ({@damage 3d6}) fire damage.

action.name: Longsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d8 + 3}) slashing damage plus 10 ({@damage 3d6}) fire damage.

action.name: Hurl Flame
entries: {@atk rs} {@hit 4} to hit, range 150 ft., one target. {@h}14 ({@damage 4d6}) fire damage. If the target is a flammable object that isn't being worn or carried, it also catches fire.

variant.name: Devil Summoning
entries: The abigor can have an action option that allows it to summon another devil.

entries.name: Summon Devil (1/Day)
entries: The abigor has a {@chance 30|30 percent|30% summoning chance} chance of summoning one abigor mounted on a nightmare.

trait.name: Immutable Form
entries: The barathrum is immune to any spell or effect that would alter its form.

trait.name: Keen Smell
entries: The barathrum has advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on smell.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The barathrum has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Magic Weapons
entries: The barathrum's weapon attacks are magical.

trait.name: Regeneration
entries: The barathrum regains 10 hit points at the start of its turn if it has at least 1 hit point.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The barathrum makes three attacks, one bite and two fist attacks.

action.name: Ham-sized Fist
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}14 ({@damage 2d8 + 5}) bludgeoning damage. Instead of dealing damage, the barathrum can grapple the target (escape {@dc 15}) provided it is Medium or smaller. Until this grapple ends, the target is {@condition restrained}, and the barathrum can't bite any target except one that it has {@condition grappled}. The barathrum has two pairs of arms, each of which can grapple one target. If it grapples two creatures, then it can't make fist attacks

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}31 ({@damage 4d12 + 5}) piercing damage.

action.name: Swallow
entries: The barathrum makes one bite attack against a Medium or smaller creature it is grappling. If the attack hits, that creature takes the bite's damage, the grapple ends and it is swallowed. While swallowed, the creature is {@condition blinded} and {@condition restrained}, it has total cover against attacks and other effects outside the barathrum. Only one creature can be swallowed at a time. A swallowed creature must make a {@dc 17} Strength saving throw at the end of each of its turns. If the creature fails, it is pulled into the bag of devouring gullet and destroyed. If the barathrum takes 40 or more slashing or piercing damage on a single turn from a swallowed creature, the barathrum must immediately succeed on a {@dc 20} Constitution saving throw or it ruptures and the entire barathrum is destroyed. Anything swallowed is scattered randomly in the Astral Plane. If the barathrum dies without rupturing, a swallowed creature is no longer {@condition restrained} by it and can escape from the corpse using 5 feet of movement, exiting {@condition prone}.

trait.name: Limited Magic Resistance
entries: The blackthraw has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects, except against banishment, dispel good and evil or any effect that returns a fiend to its home plane.

trait.name: Seal Fate
entries: As a bonus action, the blackthraw targets one creature it can see within 120 feet and chooses whether it has advantage or disadvantage on its death saving throws. The blackthraw can change the target as a bonus action.

trait.name: Spurn Luck (1/Day)
entries: As a bonus action, the blackthraw can target one creature it can see within 120 feet. The blackthraw chooses to give it advantage or disadvantage on all attack rolls, saving throws or ability checks it makes on its next turn. During the creature's very next turn, it has the opposite (advantage or disadvantage) of the blackthraw's choice on those rolls.

trait.name: Two Heads
entries: The blackthraw has advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks and on saving throws against being {@condition blinded}, {@condition charmed}, {@condition deafened}, {@condition frightened}, {@condition stunned} and knocked {@condition unconscious}.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The blackthraw makes two attacks with its beaks.

action.name: Beak
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d4 + 2}) piercing damage

reaction.name: It is Written (Recharge after a Short or Long Rest)
entries: The blackthraw targets a creature within 120 feet that it can see and gives it a +10 bonus to its next attack roll, saving throw or ability check. The blackthraw must do this before the roll is made.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The blackthraw's spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 12}). The blackthraw can innately cast the following spells, requiring only verbal components:

monster.name: Cankerbeast
languages: telepathy (only with creatures it is touching)

trait.name: Aggressive
entries: As a bonus action, the cankerbeast can move up to its speed toward a hostile creature that it can see.

trait.name: Compelled Speech
entries: Using the host, the cankerbeast can produce speech. A {@dc 15} Wisdom (Insight) check detects strain and discomfort.

trait.name: Urticating Hairs (Recharge 6)
entries: As a bonus action, the cankerbeast can rub loose its fine, poisonous hairs. Each creature within 10 feet of the cankerbeast must make a {@dc 16} Constitution saving throw. If the saving throw fails by 5 or more, the creature is instantly {@condition blinded} and takes 7 ({@damage 2d6}) poison damage. Otherwise, a creature that fails the saving throw is {@condition poisoned} and takes 7 ({@damage 2d6}) poison damage. A {@condition poisoned} creature must repeat the saving throw at the end of its next turn, becoming blind on a failure or ending the effect on a success. The blindness lasts until the creature finishes a short or long rest or magic such as the lesser restoration spell removes it.

trait.name: Reactive Hands
entries: For each of the cankerbeast's clawed hands that isn't maintaining a grapple, it gets an extra reaction that can be used only for opportunity attacks.

trait.name: Regeneration
entries: The cankerbeast regains 5 hit points at the start of its turn if it has at least 1 hit point.

trait.name: Vicious Embrace
entries: If the cankerbeast hits the same Large or smaller creature with both its claw attacks on the same turn, the creature is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 13}). Until this grapple ends, the target is {@condition restrained} and the cankerbeast can't grapple another target and can't use its bite attack on another target.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The cankerbeast makes three attacks: one with its bite and two with its claws.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}16 ({@damage 3d8 + 3}) piercing damage.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d8 + 3}) slashing damage.

action.name: Birthing Retch (Recharge 6)
entries: As an action, the host's mouth vomits a cankerbeast larva onto a {@condition grappled} creature. The target must succeed on a {@dc 16} Constitution saving throw, taking 14 ({@damage 4d6}) poison damageon a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. The new larva acts immediately before the cankerbeast's next turn.

legendary.name: Claw Attack
entries: The cankerbeast makes one claw attack.

legendary.name: Grappling Hands
entries: Using the host's vestigial arms, the cankerbeast can hold a creature that is {@condition grappled} by its Vicious Embrace. Until the end of the {@condition grappled} creature's next turn, it makes escape checks at disadvantage.

legendary.name: Anguished Scream (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: The host's mouth produces a mind-rending scream audible within 300 feet. Other than cankerbeasts, creatures within 60 feet that can hear must succeed on a {@dc 13} Wisdom saving throw or be {@condition frightened} until the end of the cankerbeast's next turn.

monster.name: Cankerbeast Larva
languages: telepathy (only with creatures it is touching)

trait.name: Amorphous
entries: The larva can move through a space as narrow as 1 inch wide without squeezing.

trait.name: Limited Telepathy
entries: The larva can communicate simple ideas, emotions and images telepathically with any creature it is touching that can understand a language.

trait.name: Spider Climb
entries: The larva can climb difficult surfaces, including upside down on ceilings, without needing to make an ability check.

trait.name: Swarm-like
entries: The larva can occupy another creature's space and vice versa.

action.name: Pseudopod
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +2} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}2 ({@damage 1d4}) bludgeoning damage plus 3 ({@damage 1d6}) poison damage, and the target must succeed on a {@dc 13} Wisdom saving throw or become {@condition charmed} until the end of the larva's next turn. While {@condition charmed} in this way, the target is {@condition incapacitated}, its speed is reduced to 0 and the larva has advantage on attack rolls against it.

action.name: Infest
entries: The larva targets one {@condition incapacitated} or willing humanoid that it is touching. The target must succeed on a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw or be infected with a disease—the larva successfully infests the humanoid, perpetually charming it. An infested humanoid with 0 hit points immediately stabilizes.
Only a small portion of the larva infests the humanoid. The husk that remains outside dissolves in minutes or if it receives any damage.
After each long rest, an infested humanoid must succeed on a {@dc 8} Wisdom saving throw or suffer the effects of one form of long-term madness (see the Dungeon Master's Guide).
It takes 3 months for the larva inside the humanoid to develop into a cankerbeast. If the humanoid is targeted by an effect that cures disease before the process completes, the larva disintegrates.

trait.name: Aura of Death
entries: Any hostile creature that ends its turn within 30 feet of Hogsblood cannot heal and must make a {@dc 22} Constitution saving throw, unless Hogsblood is {@condition incapacitated}. On a failed save, the creature gains a level of {@condition exhaustion}.

trait.name: Brute
entries: Hogsblood deals an extra die of damage when he hits with a melee weapon (included in the attack).

trait.name: Infernal Chains
entries: Hogsblood wears an iron belt with four stout 15-foot chains and neck manacles that hold four victims. Each provides him with temporary hit points equal to their own and his Minion's Grasp Legendary Action (see the 'Chained Minions' sidebar). The coldiron chains can be attacked as an object (AC21, 40 hit points, resistance to slashing and bludgeoning, immunity to piercing, poison and psychic damage).

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (4/Day)
entries: If Hogsblood fails a saving throw, he can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: Hogsblood has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Magic Weapons
entries: Hogsblood's weapon attacks are magical.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: Hogsblood makes four melee attacks, using any combination of claws and weapons. Humblemaker counts as two attacks.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 16} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}18 ({@damage 2d8 + 9}) slashing damage.

action.name: Gleed, Cinder Beard (+1 Flaming Axe Hand)
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 17} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}20 ({@damage 3d6 + 10}) slashing damage plus 14 ({@damage 4d6}) fire damage. If the target is a creature and below 40 hit points, it must succeed on a {@dc 18} Constitution saving throw or be instantly slain—its head removed and flesh burnt to ashes.

action.name: Humblemaker (+1 Lead Maul)
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 17} to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. {@h}31 ({@damage 6d6 + 10}) bludgeoning damage plus 21 ({@damage 6d6}) necrotic damage. If the target is a creature, it must make a {@dc 18} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone} and {@condition stunned} until the end of its next turn.

action.name: Praise Breaker (+1 Silver Mace)
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 17} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}20 ({@damage 3d6 + 10}) bludgeoning damage plus 14 ({@damage 4d6}) necrotic damage. If the target is benefiting from an ongoing spell, Praise Breaker acts as a dispel magic spell with +8 spellcasting ability.

reaction.name: Tactical Anticipation
entries: Hogsblood can force a reroll on any attack roll made by him or another creature that he can see. The result from the second roll must be used.

legendary.name: Minion's Grasp
entries: A minion moves up to 15 feet from Hogsblood and attacks or takes the Use an Object action (see the 'Chained Minions' sidebar). The same minion can't be used more than once in the same turn for this Legendary Action.

legendary.name: Goading Gaze (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: Hogsblood can select a creature within 60 feet that he can see and that can see him. It must make a {@dc 22} Wisdom saving throw or be goaded into melee combat by his fierce gaze. On a failed saving throw, the target has Disadvantage on attack rolls against any creature other than Hogsblood and uses its full movement to approach him and engage in melee (if possible). The creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns. If successful, the effect ends and the creature is immune to Goading Gaze for the next 24 hours. The effect also ends, but the creature isn't immune, if it takes damage from anyone else or cannot see Hogsblood.

legendary.name: At Will Spell (Costs 3 Actions)
entries: Hogsblood casts either the fireball or wall of fire spell.

trait.name: Shapechanger
entries: The doppelganger can use a bonus action to polymorph into a Small or Medium humanoid it has seen, or back into its true form. Its statistics, other than its size, are the same in each form. Any equipment it is wearing or carrying isn't transformed. It reverts to its true form if it dies.

trait.name: Sly Skirmish
entries: If the doppelganger surprises a creature and hits it with an attack during the first round of combat, the target takes an extra 10 ({@dice 3d6}) damage from the attack.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The doppelganger makes two melee attacks.

action.name: Slam
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d6 + 4}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Read Thoughts
entries: The doppelganger magically reads the surface thoughts of one creature within 60 feet of it. The effect can penetrate barriers, but 3 ft. of wood or dirt, 2 ft. of stone, 2 inches of metal, or a thin sheet of lead blocks it. While the target is in range, the doppelganger can continue reading its thoughts, as long as the doppelganger's concentration isn't broken (as if concentrating on a spell). While reading the target's mind, the doppelganger has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Insight}) and Charisma ({@skill Deception}, {@skill Intimidation}, and {@skill Persuasion}) checks against the target.

reaction.name: Arcane Misdirection (3/Day)
entries: If a creature can see the doppelganger, is within 60 feet of it and casts a non-area of effect spell that targets one or more creatures, then the doppelganger can twist the spell's effect. The caster must succeed on a {@dc 14} Intelligence saving throw or the doppelganger can choose one creature (other than the caster) that is within range for the spell to target. If the caster's saving throw is successful or the target is invalid (for whatever reason), then the caster is unaffacted.

trait.name: Fleshsplitter
entries: The doppelganger can use its action to split itself into two individual versions of its current form. To maintain the effect, it must concentrate as if it were a spell. Each version has the same statistics as the original doppelganger, but only half of the doppelganger's current hit points (rounded down). Any equipment it is wearing or carrying isn't duplicated. The two versions always share the same appearance and same pool of resources (per turn, short rest, long rest, per day abilities and spells).

The first of the two versions to be reduced to 0 hit points doesn't roll death saving throws, but immediately evaporates into nothingness. If the doppelganger loses concentration or the doppelganger chooses to end the effect while both versions are intact, the doppelganger selects one version to "reform to". The recombined form retains any remaining resources and collective hit points and suffers or benefits from all conditions or spells affecting either version.

trait.name: Mouth of Madness
entries: The doppelganger is immune to the {@spell confusion} spell and similar magic, but suffers from one form of Indefinite Madness (see the Dungeon Master's Guide). Also, roll a {@dice d10} at the start of each of the doppelganger's turns during combat to determine its action for the turn:
1–1. The doppelganger experiences vivid delusions of grandeur and has disadvantage on ability checks and attack rolls.
2–2. The doppelganger does whatever anyone tells it to do that isn't obviously self-destructive.

3–3. The doppelganger uses its action to shapechange into a humanoid it finds impressive, refers to itself in the third-person and stubbornly remains in that form until a 4 or 5 is rolled or combat ends.

4–5. The doppelganger becomes incredibly jealous of one of its enemies. It uses its action to shapechange into that enemy's likeness and repeats whatever it says in a stupid voice. It apes the enemy and stubbornly remains in that form until a 3 is rolled or combat ends. While in that form, it prefers to attack the enemy it is mimicking
6–10. The doppelganger behaves 'normally'.

entries: If Eshaedra fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

entries: Eshaedra's weapon attacks are magical and deal an extra 3 ({@damage 1d6}) lightning damage on a hit (included in the attacks).

action.name: Bite

action.name: Claw

action.name: Tail

action.name: Frightful Presence
entries: Each creature of Eshaedra's choice that is within 120 feet of the dragon and aware of her must succeed on a {@dc 19} Wisdom saving throw or become {@condition frightened} for 1 minute. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. If a creature's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the creature is immune to her Frightful Presence for the next 24 hours.

action.name: Lightning Breath {@recharge 5}
entries: Eshaedra exhales lightning in a 100-foot line that is 5 feet wide. On a successful save, the creature takes half as much damage and isn't pushed.

reaction.name: Wrathful Burst
entries: When Eshaedra is damaged by a melee attack, she can release a surge of thunderous force in a 10-foot radius. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 19} Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, a creature takes 18 ({@damage 4d8}) thunder damage and is pushed 10 feet away. On a successful save, the creature takes half as much damage and isn't pushed.

legendary.name: Tail Attack

entries: Magical darkness doesn't impede the devil's darkvision.

trait.name: Inseparable
entries: A gerasa can cast {@spell misty} step at will, as long as it teleports within 5 feet of one of its brother devils in its unit.

trait.name: One Blood
entries: A gerasa combines its hit points with the largest group of brother devils within 300 feet, creating one pool. If the pool is reduced to 0, then all contributing gerasa die. If a gerasa moves more than 300 feet from the group, divide the hit point pool by the number of gerasa. The separated gerasa takes its portion. If it is less than 1, it dies.

trait.name: One Defiance
entries: When a gerasa and on or more of its brother devils make a saving throw against the same effect, they all use the highest result among them.

trait.name: One Sword
entries: A gerasa has advantage on attack rolls if at least one gerasa from its unit is adjacent to it. If there are eight or more gerasa in a group (see One Blood), each gerasa can make an additional attack as a bonus action.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The gerasa makes two melee attacks or two ranged attacks.

entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d8 + 3}) slashing damage.

action.name: Shield Bash
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d6 + 3}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Javelin
entries: {@atk mw,rw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft. or range 30/120 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d6 + 3}) piercing damage.

trait.name: Dimensional Disruption.

On a success, a creature only takes half damage and isn't {@condition restrained}.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The githyanki makes two silver greatsword attacks.

action.name: Silver Greatsword +3

trait.name: Spider Climb
entries: The spider can climb difficult surfaces, including upside down on ceilings, without needing to make an ability check.

trait.name: Sand Camouflage
entries: The spider has advantage on Dexterity (Stealth) checks made to hide in sandy terrain.

trait.name: Ambusher
entries: The spider has advantage on attack rolls against any creature it has surprised.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 3} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d6 + 3}) piercing damage, plus 7 ({@damage 2d6}) poison damage and the target must make a {@dc 11} Constitution saving throw or become {@condition poisoned} for 1 minute. While {@condition poisoned} in this way, the target is {@condition stunned}. The target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. If the poison damage reduces the target to 0 hit points, the target is stable but {@condition poisoned} for 1 hour (even after regaining hit points) and is {@condition paralyzed} while {@condition poisoned} in this way.

Abigors, the dragoons of the Nine Hells, wear ornate armor and bear shields with the heraldic devices of their lords. Their cumbersome-looking helms smoke and hiss, filled with unseen, igneous visages. Only their ember-hot eyes are visible, burning courage from otherwise stout hearts.

entries.name: Dark Devotion
entries: While they are often part of cavalry detachments, they are also sent out on critical missions or as trusted scouts. Their ability to cause searing burns that distract their foes make them ideal for hit and run attacks.

Never without their prized nightmare mounts (or other, even more frightening steeds), abigors serve their masters unswervingly. While devoted to a stygian code of honor, they will still gleefully ride down a foe whose morale has broken.

A barathrum is the result of a bonded leather hide crafted from the torsos of two ogres (or any other creatures with arms or tentacles on a hefty torso) stuffed with a spiced, exotic galimatias and a creatively used manual of golems and bag of devouring. This recipe entices part of the gigantic creature at the other end of the bag to inhabit the frame. The malleable result is only harmed by adamantine or magical weapons and is all but immune to blunt force.

entries.name: Bottomless Hunger
entries: The creature is dimly aware of its surroundings, guided by an acute sense of smell and ravenous hunger. Unlike most golems, the only control the creator has is that the barathrum doesn't eat him or her. All other animal or vegetable matter is fair game, stuffed into its mouth without a second thought.

Any creature swallowed is in deadly peril, as the core of the construct is a bag of devouring. Anything slipping into it is instantly obliterated. The barathrum has no interest in objects or inorganic constructs and won't waste the time necessary to fight or swallow them.

When a warlock or dark priest seeks a fiendish patron, devils usually answer. And while devils always keep their word -- even if it's with a twist -- many mortals are unreliable servants unless trained properly. So, devils often require that acolytes first serve as blackthraws (sometimes known a 'wyrd-agops' or 'badh-thraws') to learn strict obedience and to squeeze some of that annoying individuality from their bones.

entries.name: Odd Couple
entries: In a dark and fiery ritual, the patron fuses the petitioner with a minor, but particularly obedient minion. The result is a sizable two-headed bird resembling a raven or large crow with three legs. It is half black, the rest near-white. The more unruly or rebellious the supplicant, the whiter its half is. But as the acolyte learns to follow the example of its conjoined companions, it fades to black. Eventually, the patron dissolves the union, releasing the petitioner to serve as a warlock or priest. The impermanent nature of the union is why blackthraws are so susceptible to banishment.

entries.name: Fate, Not Luck
entries: A blackthraw is charged with ensuring obedience and success. Even chance doesn't excuse failure and mustn't spoil its patron's plans. So, it is assigned to accompany (and spy on) its patron's minions when they are sent on important missions and twist luck into success. Its relatively weak form means that its life often depends on it.

Change is inevitable, and sometimes it's hard to tell whether it's good or bad. The cankerbeast, however, leaves no doubt:the change it brings is truly horrific. Despite this certainty, little else is known about it. Sages debate whether it is an exiled devil or a refugee of an inner plane. Others point to the dead god Moander or Sigil and a creature named Slugosith.

entries.name: Poisonous Intruder
entries: A cankerbeast begins as a larva that appears similar to an olive-colored ooze with faint purple patches. In this form, it stealthily seeks out a potential humanoid host and incapacitates it with its slime. It quickly and surreptitiously inserts a long tendril into an orifice, which then detaches from the slimy green mass, infesting the humanoid's body and mind. The rest of the larva is abandoned, instantly a husk that soon dissolves.

entries.name: Growing Pains
entries: For the next three months the larva grows inside, while its increasingly weak-willed host unconciously avoids anything that could harm it. During this time, a host can be cured and the larva destroyed by magic that cures diseases. But if left untreated, the host is gradually disfigured, developing in the last month a slight hunchback, goiters or what may look like a serious bruise on its back. With just 24 hours left, the host grows weary (gains three levels of exhaustion), begins vomiting blood and its skin becomes slimy and shifts to a vile purple-green hue. When the host's swollen skin finally shreds, a viscid mucus flows out and hardens into a mature cankerbeast with complete control.

Once mature, the cankerbeast has access to its former host's mind. Memories and the humanoid's voice are eagerly used to lure potential meals. Unfortunately, the mind is also clouded by the humanoid's insanity-inducing condition.

entries.name: Direct Deposit
entries: Each cankerbeast incubates larvae in the belly of its host. It has the option of vomiting them out to fend for themselves or ejecting them directly onto their own host. The latter covers the victim with a dark, poisonous slime containing the larva.

entries.name: Circle of Life
entries: When a host dies (from wounds, wear and tear or age), a cankerbeast consumes the remnants and reverts to larval form. It then slinks off to seek its next host.

If the cankerbeast is slaughtered, a merciful death is usually better than freeing the host. Not only is a heal spell or similarly powerful magic required to prevent immediate death, but restoring sanity may be impossible.

entries.name: Unbeliever's Embrace
entries: Embrace. The transformation into a cankerbeast seems to be a hellish pit providing enduring torment. Yet, some accept it willingly and others even worship cankerbeasts. This most frequently occurs among communities that have abandoned or outright mock the idea of serving gods in this and the next life. Instead, they seek immediate, more tangible power. Among these people, a cankerbeast can find fertile ground for its larva.

entries.name: Devilish Tools
entries: Cankerbeast cults are often established by crafty devils seeking a long-term and steady supply of corrupted souls. They teach rituals and ceremonies that celebrate the death of weakness and rebirth as a new, powerful being.

entries.name: The Chosen Few
entries: Somewhat counterintuitively, devils encourage communities to develop hierarchies to restrict the blessings of 'rebirth'. This way long-lived cankerbeasts (thought to be immortal) enslave entire communities that produce generations of hosts, and devils reap the resulting corrupted souls. Cultists believe that the host becomes one with the cankerbeast, being absorbed during each mature manifestation. They will claim to notice changes in behavior as the abomination acquires memories and preferences from a host. As a result, cultists will use both the cankerbeast's name and the name of its current host. Cultist may even take a cankerbeast's name before becoming a host, signifying their status as the next in line.

entries.name: Monstersuit Template
entries: Most who become a cankerbeast's host are truly victims of misfortune, but a few are mad enough to do so deliberately. These delusionals use aberrant rituals to bind the cankerbeast. They're convinced that this will give them complete control. They're almost always wrong.

A host that deliberately binds a cankerbeast to itself must have at least 8 hit dice to resist the mind control of the larva. The host retains its statistics except as described below. The host might retain or lose class abilities as the DM sees fit.
Ability Scores. Unless the host's ability scores are higher, they change as follows: Str 16 (+3), Con 18 (+4).
Armor Class. The host has an armor class of 15.
Speed: Climb. The host has a climb speed of 20 feet.
Damage Resistance. The host has resistance to bludgeoning, piercing and slashing damage from nonmagical weapons.
Damage Immunities. The host has immunity to fire and poison.
Condition Immunities. The host can't be poisoned.
Senses. The host has darkvision with a radius of 60 feet and blindsight with a radius of 10 feet.
Regeneration. The host regains 5 hit points at the start of its turn as long as it has at least 1 hit point.

Poisoned Mind. After each long rest, a host must succeed on a DC 8 Wisdom saving throw or suffer the effects of one form of long-term madness (see the Dungeon Master's Guide). If it fails this roll twice in a row, it suffer the effects of one form of indefinite madness. For each form of indefinite madness, the saving throw DC increases by 4. Once the DC is 20, the host is under the control of the cankerbeast.

Urticating Hairs (Recharge after a Short or Long Rest). As a bonus action, the host can rub loose fine, poisonous hairs. Each creature within 10 feet of the host must make a DC 16 Constitution saving throw. If the saving throw fails by 5 or more, the creature is instantly blinded and takes 7 ({@damage 2d6}) poison damage. Otherwise, a creature that fails the saving throw is poisoned and takes 7 ({@damage 2d6}) poison damage. A poisoned creature must repeat the saving throw at the end of its next turn, becoming blind on a failure or ending the effect on a success. The blindness lasts until the creature finishes a short or long rest or magic such as the lesser restoration spell removes it.
Legendary Actions. The host has the following legendary action options and has 2 legendary actions.
Claw. The host gains a melee weapon attack with 5-foot reach that deals 7 ({@damage 1d8 + 3}) slashing damage.
Bite (Costs 2 Actions). The host gains a melee weapon attack with 5-foot reach that deals 16 ({@damage 3d8 + 3}) piercing damage.

entries.name: Legendary Commander of Avernus
entries: Once a great general in the Nine Hells (marshal to the archdevil Beherit—now destroyed), Khal'belok was too feared and disliked by the other archdevils to win himself a new patron. So, he wandered Avernus as a warlord and mercenary. That is until the chaos introduced by Bel's betrayal Zariel and her subsequent return to power. With a tenuous hold on Avernus, Zariel needed all the allies she could find and made a careful gamble by appointing the former marshal, now bearing the sobriquet 'Captain Hogsblood', as commander of her greatest legion. He has served her successfully and—it would seem—loyally since.

entries.name: Doom Bringer
entries: Hogsblood's inspired tactics, iron leadership and personal brawn have made him the victor on many battlefields, whether in Avernus or elsewhere. While he enjoys strategy, what he truly relishes is the 'beauty' of defeated opponents. Not many in the Nine Hells appreciate this obsession, bearing intense grudges. With so many enemies, it is fortunate for him that he is feared.

If Hogsblood is impressed by a particular defeated foe or merely wishes to punish one, he chains it to his iron belt. The infernal belt transfers wounds that Hogsblood receives to the victim. And if anyone is slain while chained, their soul is permanently tied to Hogsblood—doomed to strengthen the deadly, enervating aura that surrounds him.

entries.name: Fiendish Honor
entries: Ever honorable, Hogsblood always offers to duel a single or two enemies at a time. However, this doesn't mean he'll duel without the benefit of his four chained victims (Hogsblood prefers the term 'minions') acting as living shields. And while he won't attack from ambush, those that he commands will attack whenever they have an advantage.

entries.name: Gore-Covered Horror
entries: Hogsblood is a grey-skinned pit fiend with wide, curving, bull-like horns, but has no wings or tail. He has four massive arms (his front-left ending with an axe instead of a hand) set in two opposing pairs—a front pair plus a back pair sharing two meaty shoulders. As a result, he can easily fight four opponents on four sides at once. His eyes are a brilliant, scorching yellow, and his tongue and inner mouth a vivid purple. He is fond of wearing gore covered armor composed of various demonic and humanoid carcasses—hence his widely used nickname.

entries.name: Soul Shattering Weapons
entries: His preferred weapons include Humblemaker, a strenuously large maul made of bone and lead that topples opponents with each hit, Praise Breaker, a mace ornamented with four screaming silver angels that removes enchantments from anyone struck, and Gleed, the Cinder Beard, his flaming axe affixed to one of his arms. He is unlikely to ever use a missile weapon in combat, preferring to force his enemies into melee.

entries.name: Chained Minions: Mind and Body
entries: Hogsblood always has four defeated enemies ('minions') chained to him. Not only are they physically chained to him, but mentally and spiritually. This makes him particularly fond of enslaving allies of an enemy, handing them a grim dilemma. In order of preference, he chains up enemies' allies, demons, conjurers, holy men and disobedient devils.

entries.name: Shattered Servants
entries: Some tormented minions become fractured remnants of their former selves, wielding crude iron hooks where hands once were. These minions are nicknamed 'Hogsblood's Hookers'. However, Hogsblood often uses other, more viable and talented minions to augment the arsenal of combat abilities he has available.

entries.name: Chained Minions
entries: While chained, minions are an extension of Hogsblood's body and mind. In terms of mechanics, each minion provides three things to his stat block: temporary hitpoints, one use of Legendary Resistance and a single, limited attack for the Minion's Grasp Legendary Action. They do not have a stat block of their own.

The stat block and challenge rating of 23 for Hogsblood on the previous page assumes he has four chained minions, each with 40 hit points and one the Minion's Grasp Legendary actions listed on this page. A DM should not feel constrained by the hit point total or these examples. He or she should feel free to develop custom Minion's Grasp Legendary Actions based on other monsters or NPCs.

entries.name: Proxies
entries: Chained minions act as Hogsblood's 'willing' proxies for damage and harmful effects. Mechanically, their hit points become his temporary hit points and each minion provides him with one of his four uses of Legendary Resistance. They are not targeted as specific, separate creatures, don't make their own saving throws and don't take separate damage from area effects.

entries.name: Partial Actions
entries: Chained minions are so thoroughly broken and dominated that they are only a fraction of what they were and can do very little. More specifically, regardless of the creature or its abilities, the Legendary Action it provides to Hogsblood can only consist of a single attack (no multiattack actions) or a spell or magical effect comparable to an arcane cantrip. (Divine spellcasters—good or evil—don't receive spells while enslaved.) The Legendary Action can also consist of the minion taking the Use an Object action (pick up a sword, open a door, retrieve a potion, etc.).
Examples of Minion's Grasp Legendary Actions are provided on this page.

entries.name: Demon's Sting
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 16} to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. {@h}18 ({@damage 2d8 + 9}) piercing damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a DC 18 Constitution saving throw or be poisoned. The creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

entries.name: Devil's Glaive
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 16} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}14 ({@damage 1d10 + 9}) slashing damage. If the target is a creature other than an undead or construct, it must succeed on a DC 18 Constitution saving throw or lose 11 ({@dice 2d10}) hit points at the start of each of its turns. Any creature can take an action to stanch the wound with a successful DC 12 Wisdom (Medicine) check. The wound also closes if the target receives magical healing.

entries.name: Hooker's Attack
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 16} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}16 ({@damage 2d6 + 9}) piercing damage, and the target is grappled (escape DC19) if it is Medium or smaller. Until the grapple ends, the target is restrained and takes 16 ({@damage 2d6 + 9}) piercing damage at the start of each of Hogsblood's turns.

entries.name: Knight's Brutal Attack
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 16} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}19 ({@damage 3d6 + 9}) slashing damage. When you roll a 1 or 2 on a damage die for this attack you can reroll the die, but you must use the new roll.

entries.name: Mage's Fiery Attack
entries: {@atk rs} {@hit 14} to hit, range 120 ft., one target. {@h}18 ({@damage 2d10 + 7}) fire damage and the target can't take reactions until the end of its next turn.

entries.name: Mage's Icy Attack
entries: {@atk rs} {@hit 14} to hit, range 60 ft., one target. {@h}16 ({@damage 2d8 + 7}) cold damage and target's speed is reduced by 10 ft. until the end of its next turn.
Some doppelgangers are more curious and ambitious than those satisfied with a life of indolence. They capture arcanist and get what they want using mental torture or even murder.

entries.name: Power Hungry
entries: Dooplegangers that steal the secrets of bards or consume enough arcanists' brains become fleetflesh. The knowledge they incorporate, either mentally or organically, allows them to acquire some magic, especially illusions, enchantments and counterspelling. Their talent at quickly altering their appearance becomes so potent that they can redirect some spells, instead of merely blocking them.

entries.name: Artful Combatants
entries: The fleetflesh's swift shapeshifting also allows them to confuse foes by briefly appearing as an attacker's ally or an innocent. The fleetflesh usually leverages this by working with other doppelgangers, giving them an edge in combat and, if things go poorly, a chance to blend in and escape.

A few doppelgangers are able to augment their shapechanging powers by learning the forms of various beasts. Most other doppelgangers view this as a waste of time and effort. They'd rather stay focused on assuming more civilized forms to steal money and creature comforts.
A few doppelgangers have delved too deep into their natural abilities, and learned to duplicate themselves. They are known as fleshsplitters, and this amazing feat comes at a price: sanity.

After losing her entire hoard—but escaping with her life—Eshaedra swore she'd spill rivers of blood getting back every copper piece and more! And she'd slaughter any thief that ever looked upon her hoard again. The goddess of greed and wealth heard, and the dragon priestess has amassed wealth in her name ever since, serving Tiamat for centuries.

Gerasa, also known as battle devils, are among Hell's weakest soldiers, fighting in immense units. The gerasa that make up a unit are bonded to one another through an obscene ritual using colossal fiery cauldrons. Once bonded, these 'brother devils' fight as one vast war machine.

entries.name: Strength in Numbers.
entries: Individually, gerasa are weak and dim-witted. Together, on the other hand, they become formidable and develop a collective intelligence capable of cunning tactics. Each unit has a distinctive appearance and may even favor unusual weapons or tactics. Individuals within each unit, however, are indistinguishable.

entries.name: Unswerving Orthodoxy.
entries: Gerrasa are unquestioningly loyal to their brother devils and superiors and always fight in tight clusters. Some clever foes exploit this slavish devotion.

On the Material Plane, gerasa are sometimes found in small numbers. A devil may loan a corrupt mortal a detachment of eight or ten. A much larger number, 50 or more, would require terrible sacrifices from an evil warlord.
Harriers devote their minds to folding the distance between spaces and stepping through. Unfortunately for foes with unprepared minds, the manipulation can shred their sanity.

Grimjaw hounds are living bear traps. And though one hound isn't an unusual threat, two or more are deadly -- one trips a foe and the others rip it apart. They are so tenacious that they remain clamped onto their victims after death. For these reasons armies use them as war dogs and breed them with exotic stock, like worgs and hell hounds.

Halphi, or Iron Devils, serve as the disciplined, heavy foot soldiers of the Nine Hells. From the frigid layer of Stygia, they look similar to rime-covered helmed horrors, but sealed inside are pitiless fiends that neither give quarter nor surrender ground they have taken. They are utterly loyal to their unit and commander, but hunger for glory and promotion. As a result, they selfishly place their orders and objectives above all others—trampling or even killing allies to achieve them.

entries.name: Dauntless
entries: Starting slowly, a unit of these heavily armored juggernauts is nearly impossible to stop once fully committed to an assault and are especially effective when attacking in formation. If checked, they resort to compulsion to draw out weak-willed and lightly armored foes.

Iron Devils are often deployed against spellcasters, but not because of their magic resistance. They are impossibly loud and wreak havoc with anyone's ability to concentrate—on spells or anything else. Surprise attack is impossible as any movement produces a harsh cacophony of metal grating on metal.

When a shadow rises from a corpse (see the Shadow entry in the Monster Manual) and the corpse is reanimated, dark magics can reattach the shadow and infuse the resulting anathema with the essence of the Shadowfell. These dreadful, towering horrors are macroscians and are usually created by powerful necromancers or hags seeking a potent guardian that will create additional minions as it slays.

Macroscians appear as looming darkness wielding long, twisted claws and wear withered countenances with dim, ruby eyes. The rest of their form fades into thick murkiness, spreading down to sweep across the earth.

entries.name: Shadow Trap
entries: A necromantic ritual is needed before the link between shadow and body can be reestablished. It works best when performed at a shadow crossing, forlorn places where the veil between the Material and the Shadowfell are especially porous. At the very least, a corpse must be animated on a moonless night and 'offerings' must be used to draw out and snare the shadow. Once present, the shadow must be bound to the animated corpse—called a 'shadow tether'—for it to submit to its creator. Botching this step may result in the presumptive master being dragged into the Shadowfell.

Held fast by the snare, the shadow grows and expands as negative energy pours into it from the Shadowfell. Rapidly, the bedimmed atrocity fully envelopes its shadow tether. Completely swallowed by the murky shadow-stuff, the reanimated corpse is shielded, existing in a 'gloom shroud'—akin to a perpetual shadow crossing.

entries.name: Tenuous Mooring
entries: With so much dark energy inside the macroscian, the tug of the Shadowfell is strong. Only the shadow tether, usually a skeleton or zombie, keeps it on the Material Plane. If the shadow tether is destroyed, the shadow half is instantly shunted back to the Shadowfell where it dissolves into nothingness. The macroscian does all it can to prevent this.

entries.name: Doorway to Darkness
entries: Despite this relatively straight forward weakness, destroying the shadow tether is perilous. To harm it, one must force their way into the macroscian itself. Anyone that gets past the macroscian's claws and plunges into the complete darkness will find that they has only moments before the lethal domain quickly drains away their strength.

entries.name: Grim Choice
entries: Like other shadows, the macroscian is motivated by a bestial hunger for violence and murder. As long as its creator provides victims to satisfy this craving, he or she enjoys absolute obedience. Each victim yields up its shadow, which falls under the macroscian's sway. If the macroscian goes wanting, it and its offspring become enraged. This traps the creator in a frightful dilemma: do you keep feeding the macroscian and increase its power or stop feeding it and prepare to face a dark, frenzied maelstrom.

entries.name: Undead Nature
entries: A macroscian doesn't require air, food, drink or sleep.

entries.name: Undead Inside: Shadow Tether
entries: A shadow tether is the corporeal half of the macroscian and stands inside the Large shadow, inside its Gloom Shroud. The Gloom Shroud is a 10-foot by 10-foot area of magical darkness. The shadow tether cannot interact with anything outside the Gloom Shroud and nothing outside can interact with it. When another creature forces its way in, the shadow tether is pushed into an unoccupied square in the 10-foot by 10-foot space.
The shadow tether has the statistics of a normal undead of its type (usually a skeleton or zombie) with the following additional traits, if not already present:

entries.name: Bounded Blindsight
entries: While inside the Gloom Shroud, the shadow tether has blindsight with a radius of 5 feet.

entries.name: Dimly Seen
entries: From the outside, noticing the shadow tether hidden within the Gloom Shroud requires a passive Wisdom (Perception) score of 15 or a successful check.

entries.name: Shadowfell Weapons
entries: Attacks by the shadow tether deal an additional 7 ({@damage 2d6}) necrotic damage.

entries.name: Undead Fortitude
entries: If damage reduces the undead to 0 hit points, it must make a Constitution saving throw with a DC of 0 + the damage taken, unless the damage is radiant or from a critical hit. On a success, the undead drops to 1 hit point instead.

Cunning manipulators, the ruthless mindsnare nagas are determined to impose their yoke upon lessers. Not lacking in hubris, this includes any society from primitive goblin tribes to yuan-ti or even the most powerful of fire giant clans.

entries.name: Methodical Usurpers
entries: Their penchant for subtlety means that they rely on control of others to further their goals. To obtain this, they carefully observe a lawful society, then charm or blackmail the leadership. Eventually, they either become the power behind the throne or the former elites ceremoniously hand rulership over to their new master.

entries.name: Silver-Tongued Despots
entries: The nagas' enchanting words, probing gaze and intoxicating venom make any encounter treacherous. Though they prefer to subdue aggressors before violence erupts, they can still bend enemies into allies during battle. Captured foes have been known to become devoted thralls after hours of torment under the naga's gaze.

entries.name: Den of Treachery
entries: Mindsnare naga lairs always include pits, high daises or other impediments to delay attackers long enough for enchantments to take effect.

Failure to achieve lichdom is catastrophic—worse than death. But a wrong turn isn't always a dead-end. Of the arcanists that become nothics, a rare few—whether by a fortunate discovery or accumulated knowledge—gain an awareness of their former selves. This confers significant power—power they may not be ready for—and pushes them one step closer to escaping their twisted form. This invigorates and empowers the nothics' dark hope of a second chance at eldritch undeath; even if it may be just another sadistic twist designed by dark powers to cultivate ever greater forms of madness.

entries.name: Fractured Arcanists
entries: As with their distorted bodies, nothic minds are twisted with compulsive behaviors and ticks. With the addition of many years and an awareness of former power, these problems amplify. The resulting suspicions and ritualistic observances come to firmly rule their tortuous minds, and visitors can run afoul of either, resulting in curious questioning, torment or almost instant disintegration.

entries.name: Baleful Obsession
entries: The attention of a nothic savant may be worse than the ire of a revenant. If they believe there is even just a mere scrap of useful knowledge inside a victim's mind, they will ruthlessly scour it clean.

Anything nonthreatening or irrelevant to the nothic's goal is ignored. This means that they may continue searching a tome during an earthquake or take only one artifact from a slain dragon's hoard. While obsessed, they will still flee if necessary; death is the ultimate obstacle.

entries.name: Living Library
entries: Nothic savants often lair in repositories of information, such as schools or abandoned libraries. As a result of this and their desperate hunger for knowledge, they are tempting targets for the powerful and curious. They aren't ignorant of this. So, nothic savants aggressively barter or leverage their position to pry secrets from others. Some even use blackmail. However, their solitary, uncooperative nature and crushing paranoia make creating and controlling a network of spies and agents almost unthinkable.

entries.name: Cautious Killers
entries: Nothic savants would no sooner burn a book they hadn't read than kill someone on sight. Their monomania demands that they determine whether or not any intelligent creature they encounter has some clue that will help them achieve their ultimate goal. They'll first observe, usually using their truesight while obscured by magical darkness or fog. If they determine that a creature doesn't have or know anything useful, it is considered a potential meal and attacked (from concealment). Only other nothics exceed this rule; their ability to gather lore makes them more useful alive.

entries.name: A Nothic Savant's Lair
entries: Since the nothic savant is convinced that it still has a chance to become a lich, it collects knowledge at a frenetic pace. Over decades—almost as a physical manifestation of obsession—its lair becomes piled with the detritus of failed experiments, eldritch cul-de-sacs and projects 'in progress' or abandoned. The debris may even become so deep that an odd apparatus of Kwalish or lair guardian will lie beneath. All of this makes walking a bit tricky.

In addition to creating a treacherous network riddled with hidden passages and intentional or accidental traps, the mounds of books (whole or shredded in fits of frustration), shattered staves, snapped wands, magical beast bones, torn cloaks, broken weapons and decaying spell components spill arcane energy, infusing the lair with latent power. The nothic savant draws on this to ward the area against potentially devastating fires (flames are extinguished and fire spells fail instantly) and protect it from intruders.

At the heart of the rubbish is the nothic savant's 'nest', where it keeps its greatest treasures. Even if the nothic savant is defeated, the nest is so deep into the warren that finding its treasures and anything else of value may prove impossible and deadly.
A nothic savant in its lair has a challenge rating of 11 (7,200 XP)

entries.name: Lair Dangers
entries: To simulate the danger and confusion of the nothic savant's labyrinth, treat the lair as if it is protected by a permanent guards and wards spell and make the terrain difficult for everyone but the nothic savant and minions it controls. The lair may also be dotted with mundane traps (strategically or accidentally balanced piles, collapsing floors, volatile chemicals, sharp or heavy objects, etc.) and—since nothics distrust the living—animated objects, defective constructs and/or undead servants.

There is a lengthy transition from the instinctive, near-bestial nothic to the nothic savant. A common nothic only starts the journey if it discovers a significant arcane secret (perhaps a tome of clear thought). Then, as its awareness grows, it begins to retrace the steps of its arcane past and tediously renews its art. This liminal state is the nothic ascendant.

The genesis of these foul abominations was likely an ancient ritual carelessly conducted by Varpak worshipping ogres. A vengeful, dark deity—most likely Ggorulluzg, but perhaps Tharizdun or the demon lord Juiblex—was offended and cursed the ogres. Strangely, hundreds of years later this hideous curse continues to strike, albeit rarely. Either the slighted deity still holds a grudge or ogres, slow to learn, continue to make the same mistake—generation after generation.

entries.name: Offensive to the Senses
entries: Uglier and even fouler smelling than their full bodied cousins, ogre slugs are unmistakable: the somewhat-limacine upper body of an ogre and the lower half of a giant slug. A mature adult weighs more than a thousand pounds, stands 8 feet tall and grows nearly 15 feet long. Every inch is covered with a slimy, rubbery hide, making bludgeoning weapons particular ineffective. Coloring is usually pale and swampy gray-green on the upper half, becoming darker along the tail. Alarmingly, ogre slugs are even more thoughtlessly violent and ceaselessly hungry than either their ogre or slug components.

The loathsome hybrids lair in dank, dingy caverns. They consume almost anything, including their own eggs and young if sufficiently hungry, but humanoid flesh is relished and few victims are ever kept as slaves. Ogre slugs have an unusual and disturbing affection for giant slugs and often train them to guard their lairs.

entries.name: Cursed Outcasts
entries: In many ways, ogre slugs are to ogres what driders are to drow—disfigured outcasts, cursed by a god. Yet, unlike driders, the transformation process is not instant and usually isn't isolated to one individual in a tribe. The process may take months and may even go unnoticed by other ogres, until an ogre slug inevitably begins eating other tribe members. At that point, whatever ogre slugs exist either eat the remaining ogres or are driven off.

entries.name: Horde or Hermit
entries: Ogre slugs are only found in groups if an especially large warrior or shaman (a gifted individual beholden to any being willing to grant power through prayer or pact to such repugnant things) establishes dominance. These 'charismatic' figures grow the size of their tribe to include many slugs and make alliances with less tasty cave dwellers, like troglodytes. Areas around any such group—above and below ground—are quickly stripped of resources. If some outside force does not put a stop to the raids, the tribe usually implodes once food becomes scarce.

When the Yugola, the original rulers of Gehenna, created the Yugoloths, they crafted each with a purpose. Among their needs, the Yugola coven had a great many treasures and locations that they jealously wished to protect. So, guardians were scattered across the Lower Planes and beyond. The fiends protecting coins or baubles were no more powerful than goblins, but those that stood sentinel over dark secrets and strongholds were the peers of solars and balors.

entries.name: Unexceptional Origin
entries: One especially minor guardian was assigned to watch over an icy island outpost between the Plane of Water and the Plane of Air. For centuries, it grudgingly performed its duty in solitude, without word from the coven or any overseer. To pass the time, it traded with (and stole from) locals, collecting lore on obscure locations, arcane runes and ancient secrets. Much of what it learned, it then carved into its own pallid green hide.

entries.name: Unexpected Visitor
entries: At one point during the centuries, the Yugola coven dissolved into violent arguments when pages in a Book of Keeping were destroyed. The resulting chaos made the lonely guardian and its outpost even more forgettable. But, the least of the hags remembered, absconding to the redoubt with a fragmented Book of Keeping.

entries.name: Pact and Power
entries: When she arrived, the night hag was about to destroy the guardian to cover her trail, but realized the potential of its accumulated knowledge. She offered to use the secrets inscribed on the yugoloth's hide to imbue it with fierce power drawn from the surrounding planes. All it had to do was guard her 'little' book until she came back to claim it. Hungry for importance, the fiend agreed. Her ritual wrapped the creature with hurricane-like winds and encased it in a thick layer of ice. Beneath it all, fused to its body, was the Book of Keeping. She named it Selktas-Veld.

entries.name: Wandering Sentinel
entries: The pact transformed the fiend into a mighty altraloth. As part of the deal with the hag, it wouldn't stay in a single place for long. It would travel to the places it had learned of long ago, be they in the Lower, Astral or Prime Material Planes. In the eons since, the night hag disappeared—still in hiding or perhaps destroyed. But Selktas-Veld continues to wander with its prized hide (and the true names of many fiends) still intact. And to its delight, those with precious knowledge—whether foolish or brave—pursue.

entries.name: Frigid Shadow
entries: Selktas-Veld is a towering monolith of biting ice and frost, veiled by shadow and whipping winds. Its gelid wings seems to dissolve in the gloom and gusts. Wherever Selktas-Veld is present, the landscape quickly transforms into a windswept tundra. So savage is the magical winter pouring from the fiend that water within hundreds of yards quickly freezes and nonmagical fires, even bonfires, extinguish within a minute. The only trace of warmth found anywhere is Selktas-Veld's dim, red eyes, flickering like dying candles.

entries.name: Special Snowflake
entries: Above all else, Selktas-Veld cherishes its uniqueness as the only keeper of the hag's much sought after book. A close second is that it enjoys freezing solid anyone that comes looking for it, taking one treasure—the more distinctive, the better—from each. These trophies, magical or mundane, feed its immense ego. It will scour the planes for anyone that has stolen even just one.

entries.name: (Close to) Real Spiders!
entries: Each of these spider stat-blocks represent adaptations of real-world spider genera or subfamilies: Mastophora genus (American bolas spiders); Satlicinae subfamily of the Salticidae (jumping spiders); Deinopis genus (gladiator spiders); and Scytodes genus (spitting spiders). None of these spiders weave a typical radiant web and wait for prey to accidentally fly into it. Each is either an ambusher or proactive hunter and only the jumping spider hunts during the day.

entries.name: Bolas Spider (Mastophora)
entries: Bolas spiders hang above, camouflaged (often disguised as bird droppings) and rely on an unusual, adhesive droplet of silk on the end of a line. They draw prey close using pheromones to trick specific prey into believing a mate is near. (In game terms, the charmed creature believes that its favorite, enticing thing is very near—food, beer, a specific woman's perfume, etc.) Then they swing their sticky 'bolas' and snare the distracted prey. This feat isn't accomplished using poor eyesight, but their precise 'hearing'. Snared prey is quickly pulled upward and given a debilitating bite.

entries.name: Jumping Spiders (Satlicinae)
entries: Jumping spiders are active day-time hunters that jump several times the length of their bodies. They use their silk to stabilize jumps or prevent a fall when prey shake them off. Rather intelligent for spiders, they often spend time assessing prey. Then they creep forward, attach their silk safety-line and leap onto their victim to deliver a paralyzing bite.

entries.name: Gladiator Spider (Deinopis)
entries: Also known as ogre-faced net-casting spiders, these crafty hunters catch their prey using a rectangular, woolly web net. While hanging above, they hold the net downward, parallel to the ground using their long front legs. They wait and ensnare passing prey, then wrap the woolly fibers around them to make escape nearly impossible. For an extra advantage, gladiator spiders have very large eyes that give them a wide field of vision and better night vision than cats or owls.

entries.name: Spitting Spider (Scytodes)
entries: Spitting spiders spew venom-soaked webs that paralyze their prey. Yet, with unusually poor eye-sight (even for a spider) and only six eyes instead of the usual eight, they need other ways to locate prey. So, they hunt at night, use their powerful sense of 'hearing' and often use their long front legs as feelers. As a result, they are slow, but stealthy hunters. This usually gives them the chance to spit several times if their prey is larger or difficult to subdue.

entries.name: Giant Six-Eyed Sand Spider
entries: The six-eyed sand spider (Sicarius hahni) buries itself beneath desert sand and waits. When it senses prey, it springs out and delivers a bite with potent necrotic venom.

legendaryGroup.name: Nothic Savant
lairActions: On initiative count 20 (losing initiative ties), the nothic savant takes a lair action to cause one of the following effects; the nothic savant can't use the same effect two rounds in a row.

items: The nothic savant quickly assess the defenses of one enemy it can see within 90 feet and determines its strongest or weakest saving throw.

The nothic savant targets one creature it can see within 90 feet of it. The target must succeed on a DC 13 Intelligence saving throw or be shrouded in darkness. The darkness travels with it and covers whatever square(s) the target occupies. The effect lasts until initiative count 20 comes on the next round or until the nothic savant or the target leaves the lair. Otherwise, the darkness has the same properties as the {@spell darkness} spell.

The nothic savant triggers a collapse of debris that targets a 10-foot by 10-foot area it can see within 30 feet. Anyone within the area must make a DC 13 Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, the creature takes 14 ({@damage 4d6}) nonmagical damage of the nothic savant's choice and is {@condition restrained} until it or someone else pulls it free. A creature {@condition restrained} by the debris or someone adjacent to the creature can use its action to make a DC 13 Strength check to free the creature.
